abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of the project is
            satisfactory, since most of its institutional reform
            objectives were met, as were the projected agricultural
            output levels. Regardless of success, the key lessons convey
            that: 1) on policy matters, sector reforms produce major
            impacts when complemented by adequate sector investments,
            proven by the ample effect of price and trade measures, and,
            enhanced by investments in agriculture and irrigation.
            Investments and sector reforms should be placed within a
            conducive macro framework, i.e., proper currency valuation
            in a low inflationary environment; 2) on institutional
            matters, the creation of a special commission, which can
            prove effective with difficult institutional reforms,
            particularly when it involves more that one entity, should
            preferably be headed by an independent agency. Community
            involvement ensures the sustainability of irrigation
            investments, since their presence at different management
            levels may contribute to greater water fee recovery. This
            water fee should be set through an independent process, free
            from government interference; 3) on implementation matters,
            adequate coordination is essential for its synergy and
            complementarity, successfully impacts both sector policy and
            investments; and 4) on technical matters, canal design needs
            to conform to the maintenance system; and thorough technical
            monitoring is required for quality assurance.
